description:
The samurai didn't stand a chance. First, the aliens invaded Japan. Next, they took all the jobs. And then they confiscated everyone's swords. So what does a hotheaded former samurai like Sakata "Gin" Gintoki do to make ends meet? Take any odd job that comes his way, even if it means losing his dignity.

(Source: Viz Media)

Included Bonus Chapters:
Volume 1: Dandelion (One-shot).
Volume 2: Shirokuro (One-shot).
Volume 24: 13 (One-shot).
Volume 38: Bankara-san Ga Tooru (One-shot).
Volume 41: Special Lesson.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Anachronism
tags.description: Prominently features elements that are out of place in the historical period the work takes place in, particularly modern elements in a historical setting.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Ninja
tags.description: Prominently features Japanese warriors traditionally trained in espionage, sabotage and assasination.

tags.name: Ghost
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a ghost.

tags.name: Homeless
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is homeless.

tags.name: Assassins
tags.description: Centers around characters who murder people as a profession.

tags.name: Crossdressing
tags.description: Prominently features a character dressing up as the opposite sex.

tags.name: Idol
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of an idol.

tags.name: Shrine Maiden
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a shrine maiden.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

tags.name: Body Swapping
tags.description: Centers around individuals swapping bodies with one another.

tags.name: Gender Bending
tags.description: Prominently features a character who dresses and behaves in a way characteristic of another gender, or has been transformed into a person of another gender.

tags.name: Judo
tags.description: Centers around the sport of judo.

tags.name: Drawing
tags.description: Centers around the art of drawing, including manga and doujinshi.

tags.name: Gangs
tags.description: Centers around gang organizations.

tags.name: Female Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several female characters who are romantically interested in them.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Afterlife
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the afterlife.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Nekomimi
tags.description: Humanoid characters with cat-like features such as cat ears and a tail.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

node.description:
Hideaki Sorachi (空知英秋, Sorachi Hideaki) is a Japanese manga artist best known for his work Gintama.

According to his reply to a manga reader (Gintama Volume 11), he was quite interested in manga during childhood days. However at grade 4 in school he showed his work to his father who promptly laughed at it, after which Sorachi temporarily abandoned his aims of being a manga artist. After graduation, he could not find a job, thus he turned to drawing manga (which he had already learned in university). He was able to gain some recognition through his first work Dandylion and subsequently progressed in his career (the comic is shown in the first volume of Gintama, with a foreword by Hideaki stating that it was his first work). 

In 2003, Sorachi's editor attempted to coax him to create a new series due to a new television program on the Shinsengumi airing on Japanese TV the next year. Yet Sorachi's original idea was to ride on the coattails of the Harry Potter franchise with a series about a school for demon dispellers. After several arguments and an attempt to write the Shinsengumi series, Sorachi gave up, took what he had of the script and twisted it to become the pseudo-historical science fiction series Gintama. (stated in Gintama Volume 1)    

Hideaki Sorachi holds a degree in commercial advertising (again, stated in volume 11). 

(Source: Wikipedia)
Former assistant of [Hideaki Sorachi](https://anilist.co/staff/96904/Hideaki-Sorachi). The mangaka [Kentarou Yabuki](https://anilist.co/staff/96900/Kentarou-Yabuki) is his brother-in-law.
He was once assistant to [Hideaki Sorachi](https://anilist.co/staff/96904/Hideaki-Sorachi) and [Tooru Uchimizu](https://anilist.co/staff/98805/Tooru-Uchimizu).
Date is a former assistant of the mangaka [Hideaki Sorachi](https://anilist.co/staff/96904/Hideaki-Sorachi) and [Eiichirou Oda](https://anilist.co/staff/96881/Eiichirou-Oda)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/marcbernabe) |  [Official Website](https://www.japonesenvinetas.com)

He is a translator and interpreter of Japanese, with special emphasis on the translation of manga and anime, a field in which he has a background of hundreds of volumes and episodes translated. In addition, he's a  specialist in didactics of the Japanese language and culture for Spanish speakers. He also has published many books about Japan and Asia.

He is famous for appearing in a Shin-chan's episode where the family goes to Spain.
